awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Feasible Point Pursuit for Non-convex QCQPs: Algorithms and Signal Processing Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the last 20 years, convex optimization has become an indispensable design and analysis tool in science and engineering. Still, many important design and analysis problems are non-convex and NP-hard. Among them, non-convex quadratically constrained quadratic programs (QCQPs) are nowadays often encountered in wireless communications, networking, and signal processing. Examples include phased-array unicast and multicast beamforming, and phase retrieval and its applications in X-ray crystallography, optics, diffraction imaging, astronomical imaging, and microscopy. Few methods are currently effective for non-convex QCQPs, and only in special cases. This research investigates several promising new approaches to obtaining and refining feasible points for general non-convex QCQPs, and their applications in phase retrieval, beamforming, radar, and wireless networking. The project offers rich opportunities for graduate and undergraduate student engagement in cross-disciplinary research, as well as freshman and K12 outreach. 

In preliminary work, a Feasible Point Pursuit - Successive Convex Approximation (FPP-SCA) method was proposed, and initial tests revealed exciting results ? motivating further research that comprises two intertwined thrusts: one on design and analysis of new FPP methods and algorithms; and another on new signal processing applications of non-convex QCQP methods. In addition to analyzing and improving the original FPP-SCA, two new approaches are being considered. One is derived using bilinearization, leading to alternating optimization; the other using proportional fairness as a surrogate for max-min fairness, leading to low-complexity FPP using an adaptively weighted cyclically projected gradient approach. The optimality gap for fixed points of this iteration is analyzed, pertinent simplifications are pursued for special problem instances, and the link between max-min and proportional fairness is further explored ? all with an eye towards improving our fundamental understanding of non-convex QCQPs.

por.por_cntn:
Over the last 20 years, convex optimization has become an indispensable design and analysis tool in science and engineering. Still, many important design and analysis problems are non-convex and very hard. Among them, non-convex quadratically constrained quadratic programs (QCQPs) are nowadays often encountered in wireless communications and networking, signal processing, data mining, and machine learning. This project explored several promising new approaches to obtain and refine feasible points for general non-convex QCQPs, with applications in phase retrieval, beamforming, communications, and power network engineering.

Intellectual merit: Three new families of effective and scalable nonconvex QCQP approximation algorithms were developed: one based on consensus ADMM (Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers), one using successive convex approximation with fast first-order methods, and one utilizing low complexity subgradient projection. The fast projection-based non-convex QCQP feasibility solver developed under this project compares very favorably against all known state-of-the-art techniques. In addition to algorithmic advances, hidden convexity was revealed in important special cases, including Fourier phase retrieval. Fast first-order feasible point pursuit (FPP) algorithms were devised for a special class of nonconvex QCQPs, and the general non-convex QCQP feasibility problem was recast in a form that is amenable to approximation via stochastic gradient-type methods. Simple and highly affective approaches were proposed for transmit beamforming for minimum outage, and rate-optimal antenna subset selection, leveraging stochastic approximation and submodularity, respectively.

In parallel, the project made important contributions to state estimation and optimal power flow problems at the heart of power systems engineering and the smart power grid -- including formulating joint water and power flow optimization as nonconvex QCQP, and demonstrating that cross-network optimization is beneficial for both networks. Research under this project also pioneered the use of data-driven learning methods for power system state estimation, including the development of the first electrical network (physics-)aware neural network approach for power system state estimation. This significantly departs from the now widespread `black-box' incorporation of neural networks to solve all kinds of classification and estimation tasks.

Broader impacts:  Nonconvex QCQP problems are so prevalent in engineering and computer science, that the research has already had impact in several disciplines (e.g., the work on Fourier phase retrieval is already well cited in signal processing, optics, crystallography, and optimization). One PhD student (Ahmed Zamzam) graduated with primary support from this grant, and joined the National Renewable Energy Lab (NREL) in Colorado as a staff scientist. Another student involved with this grant (Aritra Konar) is now a postdoc pursuing an academic career. Zamzam and Konar won prestigious University of Minnesota Doctoral Dissertation Fellowship awards. Kejun Huang, who was involved in the early stages of this project, is currently tenure-track assistant professor at the University of Florida, Gainesville. Several more students were productively engaged in the research, and are scheduled to graduate soon.
